Despite recent advances, existing methods struggle with three key challenges: constructing tool-integrated reasoning data, performing fine-grained optimization, and enhancing inference. To overcome these limitations, we propose THOR (Tool-Integrated Hierarchical Optimization via RL). First, we introduce TIRGen, a multi-agent actor-critic-based pipeline for constructing high-quality datasets of tool-integrated reasoning paths, aligning with the policy and generalizing well across diverse models. Second, to perform fine-grained hierarchical optimization, we introduce an RL strategy that jointly optimizes for both episode-level problem solving and step-level code generation. This is motivated by our key insight that the success of an intermediate tool call is a strong predictor of the final answer's correctness. Finally, THOR incorporates a self-correction mechanism that leverages immediate tool feedback to dynamically revise erroneous reasoning paths during inference. Our approach demonstrates strong generalization across diverse models, performing effectively in both reasoning and non-reasoning models. It further achieves state-of-the-art performance for models of a similar scale on multiple mathematical benchmarks, while also delivering consistent improvements on code benchmarks. Our code will be publicly available at https://github.com/JingMog/THOR.

item.title: PRIME: Planning and Retrieval-Integrated Memory for Enhanced Reasoning
item.content:encoded: arXiv:2509.22315v2 Announce Type: replace-cross Abstract: Inspired by the dual-process theory of human cognition from \textit{Thinking, Fast and Slow}, we introduce \textbf{PRIME} (Planning and Retrieval-Integrated Memory for Enhanced Reasoning), a multi-agent reasoning framework that dynamically integrates \textbf{System 1} (fast, intuitive thinking) and \textbf{System 2} (slow, deliberate thinking). PRIME first employs a Quick Thinking Agent (System 1) to generate a rapid answer; if uncertainty is detected, it then triggers a structured System 2 reasoning pipeline composed of specialized agents for \textit{planning}, \textit{hypothesis generation}, \textit{retrieval}, \textit{information integration}, and \textit{decision-making}. This multi-agent design faithfully mimics human cognitive processes and enhances both efficiency and accuracy. Experimental results with LLaMA 3 models demonstrate that PRIME enables open-source LLMs to perform competitively with state-of-the-art closed-source models like GPT-4 and GPT-4o on benchmarks requiring multi-hop and knowledge-grounded reasoning. This research establishes PRIME as a scalable solution for improving LLMs in domains requiring complex, knowledge-intensive reasoning.

item.title: On Code-Induced Reasoning in LLMs
item.content:encoded:
vulnerable, structural perturbations, semantic perturbations, pseudocode, syntactic styles Summary: Large language models (LLMs) benefit from code data to improve reasoning abilities. A systematic study using different programming languages and controlled perturbations revealed that LLMs are more affected by structural than semantic disruptions, especially in math and code tasks. Abstract representations like pseudocode and flowcharts can be as effective as code, and compressing information with fewer tokens can maintain or enhance performance. Even corrupted code can perform well if surface-level regularities are preserved. Different syntactic styles impact task-specific performance, with Python excelling in natural language reasoning and lower-level languages like Java and Rust in math tasks. This research provides insights into how code properties influence LLM reasoning and offers guidance for enhancing their capabilities through training data design.

Summary:
arXiv:2509.21499v2 Announce Type: replace Abstract: Code data has been shown to enhance the reasoning capabilities of large language models (LLMs), but it remains unclear which aspects of code are most responsible. We investigate this question with a systematic, data-centric framework. We construct parallel instruction datasets in ten programming languages and apply controlled perturbations that selectively disrupt structural or semantic properties of code. We then finetune LLMs from five model families and eight scales on each variant and evaluate their performance on natural language, math, and code tasks. Across 3,331 experiments, our results show that LLMs are more vulnerable to structural perturbations than semantic ones, particularly on math and code tasks. Appropriate abstractions like pseudocode and flowcharts can be as effective as code, while encoding the same information with fewer tokens without adhering to original syntax can often retain or even improve performance. Remarkably, even corrupted code with misleading signals remains competitive when surface-level regularities persist. Finally, syntactic styles also shape task-specific gains with Python favoring natural language reasoning and lower-level languages such as Java and Rust favoring math. Through our systematic framework, we aim to provide insight into how different properties of code influence reasoning and inform the design of training data for enhancing LLM reasoning capabilities.

item.title: Uncovering Implicit Bias in Large Language Models with Concept Learning Dataset
item.content:encoded:
Concept learning, implicit bias, language models, dataset, quantifiers
Summary:
The article introduces a new dataset of concept learning tasks aimed at uncovering implicit biases in large language models. Through in-context concept learning experiments, the study reveals a potential bias towards upward monotonicity in quantifiers within language models. Interestingly, this bias is less pronounced when the models are tested using direct prompting devoid of concept learning components. The findings underscore the importance of utilizing in-context concept learning as an effective means of identifying hidden biases in language models.
arXiv:2510.01219v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce a dataset of concept learning tasks that helps uncover implicit biases in large language models. Using in-context concept learning experiments, we found that language models may have a bias toward upward monotonicity in quantifiers; such bias is less apparent when the model is tested by direct prompting without concept learning components. This demonstrates that in-context concept learning can be an effective way to discover hidden biases in language models.

item.title: Towards Open-Ended Discovery for Low-Resource NLP
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Natural Language Processing, low-resource languages, interactive language discovery, uncertainty-driven, human-centered AI
Summary: The article discusses the limitations faced by Natural Language Processing (NLP) in low-resource languages due to the lack of textual corpora and standardized orthographies. It argues for a shift towards interactive language discovery through dialogue rather than static datasets. The authors propose a framework that combines human-machine uncertainty to guide interaction, query selection, and memory retention. They advocate for a rethinking of how AI engages with human knowledge in under-documented languages, moving towards participatory, co-adaptive learning processes. The vision outlined in the paper aligns with human-centered AI principles, emphasizing interactive, cooperative model-building between AI systems and speakers. This approach aims to respect and empower communities while discovering and preserving linguistic diversity.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01220v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Natural Language Processing (NLP) for low-resource languages remains fundamentally constrained by the lack of textual corpora, standardized orthographies, and scalable annotation pipelines. While recent advances in large language models have improved cross-lingual transfer, they remain inaccessible to underrepresented communities due to their reliance on massive, pre-collected data and centralized infrastructure. In this position paper, we argue for a paradigm shift toward open-ended, interactive language discovery, where AI systems learn new languages dynamically through dialogue rather than static datasets. We contend that the future of language technology, particularly for low-resource and under-documented languages, must move beyond static data collection pipelines toward interactive, uncertainty-driven discovery, where learning emerges dynamically from human-machine collaboration instead of being limited to pre-existing datasets. We propose a framework grounded in joint human-machine uncertainty, combining epistemic uncertainty from the model with hesitation cues and confidence signals from human speakers to guide interaction, query selection, and memory retention. This paper is a call to action: we advocate a rethinking of how AI engages with human knowledge in under-documented languages, moving from extractive data collection toward participatory, co-adaptive learning processes that respect and empower communities while discovering and preserving the world's linguistic diversity. This vision aligns with principles of human-centered AI, emphasizing interactive, cooperative model building between AI systems and speakers.

item.title: Discourse vs emissions: Analysis of corporate narratives, symbolic practices, and mimicry through LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: climate disclosure, corporate sustainability, large language models, ESG, regulation Summary:

This paper introduces a framework using large language models to assess the maturity of climate disclosures among US-listed firms, revealing insights into the state of corporate sustainability reporting. Risk-focused narratives are often linked to explicit commitments, but quantitative targets like net-zero pledges lack alignment in tone. Larger and higher-emitting firms tend to disclose more commitments and actions but struggle with consistent quantitative targets. The analysis also uncovers a trend of mimetic behavior in disclosure styles, diminishing differentiation and decision usefulness. These findings underscore the potential of LLMs for ESG narrative analysis and emphasize the necessity for stronger regulation to ensure commitments are backed by verifiable transition strategies.
arXiv:2510.01222v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Climate change has increased demands for transparent and comparable corporate climate disclosures, yet imitation and symbolic reporting often undermine their value. This paper develops a multidimensional framework to assess disclosure maturity among 828 U.S.listed firms using large language models (LLMs) fine-tuned for climate communication. Four classifiers-sentiment, commitment, specificity, and target ambition-extract narrative indicators from sustainability and annual reports, which are linked to firm attributes such as emissions, market capitalization, and sector. Analyses reveal three insights: (1) risk-focused narratives often align with explicit commitments, but quantitative targets (e.g., net-zero pledges) remain decoupled from tone; (2) larger and higher-emitting firms disclose more commitments and actions than peers, though inconsistently with quantitative targets; and (3) widespread similarity in disclosure styles suggests mimetic behavior, reducing differentiation and decision usefulness. These results highlight the value of LLMs for ESG narrative analysis and the need for stronger regulation to connect commitments with verifiable transition strategies.

item.title: Context Matters: Comparison of commercial large language tools in veterinary medicine
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large language models, veterinary medicine, clinical NLP summarization, LLM-as-a-judge framework, veterinary oncology Summary: The study evaluated three veterinary-focused large language models (LLMs) summarization tools on veterinary oncology records. Product 1 achieved the highest overall performance, scoring well in domains such as Factual Accuracy and Chronological Order. The evaluation process using the LLM-as-a-judge framework showed high reproducibility across multiple runs. These findings emphasize the need for veterinary-specific LLM tools and demonstrate the effectiveness of using LLMs as judges in assessing clinical natural language processing (NLP) summarization in veterinary medicine. The study showcases the potential of LLMs in clinical settings and highlights the importance of accurate, complete, and clinically relevant summarization in veterinary oncology. Discovering the optimal use of LLMs in veterinary medicine could greatly benefit the field by improving efficiency and accuracy in handling clinical records.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01224v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) are increasingly used in clinical settings, yet their performance in veterinary medicine remains underexplored. We evaluated three commercially available veterinary-focused LLM summarization tools (Product 1 [Hachiko] and Products 2 and 3) on a standardized dataset of veterinary oncology records. Using a rubric-guided LLM-as-a-judge framework, summaries were scored across five domains: Factual Accuracy, Completeness, Chronological Order, Clinical Relevance, and Organization. Product 1 achieved the highest overall performance, with a median average score of 4.61 (IQR: 0.73), compared to 2.55 (IQR: 0.78) for Product 2 and 2.45 (IQR: 0.92) for Product 3. It also received perfect median scores in Factual Accuracy and Chronological Order. To assess the internal consistency of the grading framework itself, we repeated the evaluation across three independent runs. The LLM grader demonstrated high reproducibility, with Average Score standard deviations of 0.015 (Product 1), 0.088 (Product 2), and 0.034 (Product 3). These findings highlight the importance of veterinary-specific commercial LLM tools and demonstrate that LLM-as-a-judge evaluation is a scalable and reproducible method for assessing clinical NLP summarization in veterinary medicine.

item.title: ClaimCheck: Real-Time Fact-Checking with Small Language Models
item.content:encoded:
<div> fact-checking, ClaimCheck, automatic, language model, Web evidence
Summary: ClaimCheck is a new automatic fact-checking system that utilizes small language models to verify real-world claims using live Web evidence. Unlike previous systems, ClaimCheck follows a stepwise verification pipeline similar to human fact-checking workflows, involving Web search query planning, evidence retrieval and summarization, evidence synthesis, and claim verdict evaluation. Despite using a smaller Qwen3-4B model, ClaimCheck achieves a high accuracy of 76.4% on the AVeriTeC dataset, surpassing previous approaches using larger models. The system's modular design and prompting strategies effectively address the limitations of smaller language models. ClaimCheck prioritizes accessibility and transparency by providing a public demo, allowing users to test the system. <div> arXiv:2510.01226v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We introduce ClaimCheck, an LLM-guided automatic fact-checking system designed to verify real-world claims using live Web evidence and small language models. Unlike prior systems that rely on large, closed-source models and static knowledge stores, ClaimCheck employs a transparent, stepwise verification pipeline that mirrors human fact-checking workflows consisting of Web search query planning, Web-based evidence retrieval and summarization, evidence synthesis and re-retrieval, and claim verdict evaluation. Each module is optimized for small LLMs, allowing the system to deliver accurate and interpretable fact-checking with significantly lower computational requirements. Despite using a much smaller Qwen3-4B model, ClaimCheck achieves state-of-the-art accuracy of 76.4% on the AVeriTeC dataset, outperforming previous approaches using LLaMA3.1 70B and GPT-4o. Extensive ablations demonstrate that careful modular design and prompting strategies can overcome the limitations of smaller LLMs. To promote accessibility and transparency, we provide a public demo at https://idir.uta.edu/claimcheck.

item.title: EEFSUVA: A New Mathematical Olympiad Benchmark
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, mathematics benchmarks, International Mathematics Olympiad, nonstandard problem-solving techniques, model development Summary: The article examines claims that large language models (LLMs) can match Olympiad-level proficiency in mathematics. Current benchmarks, primarily based on the International Mathematics Olympiad (IMO), may overstate models' abilities due to familiar problem types and data contamination. To provide a more comprehensive assessment, a new benchmark named EEFSUVA is introduced, sourced from lesser-known regional and national Olympiads with challenging nonstandard problems. Initial results indicate that even advanced LLMs struggle with EEFSUVA compared to traditional benchmarks. The study underscores the importance of diverse evaluation datasets for accurate measurement of mathematical reasoning skills and to guide future model improvements.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01227v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent breakthroughs have spurred claims that large language models (LLMs) match gold medal Olympiad to graduate level proficiency on mathematics benchmarks. In this work, we examine these claims in detail and assess the extent to which current benchmarks capture genuine LLM mathematical reasoning. The composition of these benchmarks, primarily drawing from the International Mathematics Olympiad (IMO) and related competitions, may overstate models reasoning ability due to potential data contamination and a narrow focus on familiar problem types. To enable a more holistic assessment of mathematical understanding, we introduce EEFSUVA, a novel benchmark curated from under circulated regional and national Olympiads of Eastern Europe and the countries from the former Soviet Union. These contests feature problems of comparable difficulty to the IMO and are renowned for demanding nonstandard problem-solving techniques, yet their problems are far less prevalent in online corpora. Preliminary results suggest that even state-of-the-art LLMs exhibit a notable performance decline on EEFSUVA relative to other Olympiad-style benchmarks. These findings also suggest the potential importance of broader evaluation datasets for a fuller assessment of mathematical reasoning and for guiding future model development.

item.title: Who is In Charge? Dissecting Role Conflicts in Instruction Following
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, hierarchical instructions, social cues, conflict-decision signals, instruction following Summary: Linear probing analysis of large language models revealed that conflict-decision signals are encoded early, with distinct subspaces for system-user and social conflicts. Direct Logit Attribution showed stronger internal conflict detection in system-user cases but consistent resolution for social cues. Steering experiments demonstrated that despite using social cues, vectors amplify instruction following in a role-agnostic manner. These findings explain the fragile obedience of language models and emphasize the necessity for lightweight hierarchy-sensitive alignment methods.

Summary: Linear probing analysis identified early encoding of conflict-decision signals, with distinct subspaces for different types of conflicts. Direct Logit Attribution highlighted stronger internal conflict detection in system-user cases. Steering experiments revealed role-agnostic amplification of instruction following despite using social cues. These results emphasize the need for hierarchy-sensitive alignment methods.
arXiv:2510.01228v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models should follow hierarchical instructions where system prompts override user inputs, yet recent work shows they often ignore this rule while strongly obeying social cues such as authority or consensus. We extend these behavioral findings with mechanistic interpretations on a large-scale dataset. Linear probing shows conflict-decision signals are encoded early, with system-user and social conflicts forming distinct subspaces. Direct Logit Attribution reveals stronger internal conflict detection in system-user cases but consistent resolution only for social cues. Steering experiments show that, despite using social cues, the vectors surprisingly amplify instruction following in a role-agnostic way. Together, these results explain fragile system obedience and underscore the need for lightweight hierarchy-sensitive alignment methods.

item.title: Enhancing Transformer-Based Rerankers with Synthetic Data and LLM-Based Supervision
item.content:encoded:
semantic understanding, document reranking, Large Language Models, contrastive learning, domain-specific corpora Summary:
- Effective document reranking is crucial for enhancing search relevance in various applications. - Large Language Models (LLMs) have strong reranking abilities but are computationally expensive. - Fine-tuning smaller models with task-specific data is a more efficient alternative. - This study introduces a pipeline that generates synthetic queries using LLMs and labels query-document pairs with an LLM-based classifier. - The synthetic dataset is used to fine-tune a smaller transformer model with contrastive learning, resulting in improved reranking performance and generalization to out-of-domain tasks. - The approach reduces computational costs by utilizing LLMs for data generation and supervision rather than inference. Summary:
arXiv:2510.01229v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Effective document reranking is essential for improving search relevance across diverse applications. While Large Language Models (LLMs) excel at reranking due to their deep semantic understanding and reasoning, their high computational cost makes them impractical for many real-world deployments. Fine-tuning smaller, task-specific models is a more efficient alternative but typically depends on scarce, manually labeled data. To overcome this, we propose a novel pipeline that eliminates the need for human-labeled query-document pairs. Our method uses LLMs to generate synthetic queries from domain-specific corpora and employs an LLM-based classifier to label positive and hard-negative pairs. This synthetic dataset is then used to fine-tune a smaller transformer model with contrastive learning using Localized Contrastive Estimation (LCE) loss. Experiments on the MedQuAD dataset show that our approach significantly boosts in-domain performance and generalizes well to out-of-domain tasks. By using LLMs for data generation and supervision rather than inference, we reduce computational costs while maintaining strong reranking capabilities.

item.title: Geometric Structures and Patterns of Meaning: A PHATE Manifold Analysis of Chinese Character Embeddings
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Chinese characters, embeddings, PHATE manifold analysis, semantic organization, linguistic theory
Summary: The study examines geometric patterns in Chinese character embeddings using PHATE manifold analysis. It identifies clustering patterns for content words and branching patterns for function words across various embedding models and dimensionality reduction methods. The analysis of over 1000 Chinese characters reveals a correlation between geometric complexity and semantic content, with meaningful characters showing rich geometric diversity. Additionally, the study demonstrates a systematic semantic expansion from elemental characters through a child-network analysis of 123 phrases. These findings support traditional linguistic theory and establish a novel framework for the geometric analysis of semantic organization.
arXiv:2510.01230v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We systematically investigate geometric patterns in Chinese character embeddings using PHATE manifold analysis. Through cross-validation across seven embedding models and eight dimensionality reduction methods, we observe clustering patterns for content words and branching patterns for function words. Analysis of over 1000 Chinese characters across 12 semantic domains reveals that geometric complexity correlates with semantic content: meaningful characters exhibit rich geometric diversity while structural radicals collapse into tight clusters. The comprehensive child-network analysis (123 phrases) demonstrates systematic semantic expansion from elemental character. These findings provide computational evidence supporting traditional linguistic theory and establish a novel framework for geometric analysis of semantic organization.

item.title: Trustworthy Summarization via Uncertainty Quantification and Risk Awareness in Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: automatic summarization, uncertainty quantification, risk-aware mechanisms, information overload, high-risk decision-making Summary: This study introduces a large language model framework for automatic summarization in high-risk scenarios. By integrating uncertainty quantification and risk-aware mechanisms, the model aims to improve the reliability and trustworthiness of summaries while ensuring key information is accurately preserved. The conditional generation-based summarization model incorporates Bayesian inference to address uncertainty in the parameter space, leading to more accurate and less overconfident predictions. The model measures the uncertainty level of generated content using predictive distribution entropy and applies joint optimization of entropy regularization and risk-aware loss to enhance the robustness of summarization. By incorporating risk scoring and regulation modules, the model provides explicit risk-level prompts in the summaries, improving their trustworthiness for high-risk decision-making scenarios. Experimental results and sensitivity analyses validate the effectiveness of the proposed method in maintaining fluency and semantic integrity while improving reliability and robustness in high-risk applications. This research offers a systematic solution for trustworthy summarization with practical value at the methodological level.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01231v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This study addresses the reliability of automatic summarization in high-risk scenarios and proposes a large language model framework that integrates uncertainty quantification and risk-aware mechanisms. Starting from the demands of information overload and high-risk decision-making, a conditional generation-based summarization model is constructed, and Bayesian inference is introduced during generation to model uncertainty in the parameter space, which helps avoid overconfident predictions. The uncertainty level of the generated content is measured using predictive distribution entropy, and a joint optimization of entropy regularization and risk-aware loss is applied to ensure that key information is preserved and risk attributes are explicitly expressed during information compression. On this basis, the model incorporates risk scoring and regulation modules, allowing summaries to cover the core content accurately while enhancing trustworthiness through explicit risk-level prompts. Comparative experiments and sensitivity analyses verify that the proposed method significantly improves the robustness and reliability of summarization in high-risk applications while maintaining fluency and semantic integrity. This research provides a systematic solution for trustworthy summarization and demonstrates both scalability and practical value at the methodological level.

item.title: Benchmark Profiling: Mechanistic Diagnosis of LLM Benchmarks
item.content:encoded:
keywords: Large Language Models, Benchmark Profiling, Abilities, Model Interpretability, Benchmark Audit Summary: Benchmark Profiling introduces a method to assess the performance of Large Language Models on standard benchmarks by breaking down performance into ten cognitive abilities. It finds that most benchmarks require a mix of abilities, rather than just one, and datasets with similar labels may rely on different ability combinations. Code-generation benchmarks benefit from broad multi-skill improvement, with limited gains from narrow domain-specific fine-tuning. The presence of irrelevant abilities can negatively impact performance. This framework sheds light on why performance improvements on benchmarks may not correspond to actual user competence, offering a transparent tool for benchmark evaluation and model interpretability.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01232v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models are commonly judged by their scores on standard benchmarks, yet such scores often overstate real capability since they mask the mix of skills a task actually demands. For example, ARC is assumed to test reasoning, while HellaSwag is designed to evaluate commonsense. However, we lack a systematic way to verify if these benchmarks actually measure these labels. We introduce Benchmark Profiling, a diagnostic framework that decomposes benchmark performance into ten cognitively grounded abilities. The method combines gradient-based importance scoring with targeted parameter ablation to compute an Ability Impact Score (AIS) that quantifies how much each ability contributes to a model's success on a given benchmark. Profiling three instruction-tuned models across ten widely used benchmarks yields four key findings: (i) most benchmarks draw on several abilities rather than one, (ii) datasets with similar labels rely on distinct ability mixtures, (iii) code-generation benchmarks reward broad, multi-skill improvement and thus show only modest gains from narrow domain-specific fine-tuning, and (iv) abilities irrelevant to the task could negatively affect performance. Benchmark Profiling therefore explains why performance gains do not always translate into user-perceived competence and offers a transparent tool for benchmark audit and model interpretability.

item.title: Computational Social Linguistics for Telugu Cultural Preservation: Novel Algorithms for Chandassu Metrical Pattern Recognition
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Telugu Chandassu, computational social science, cultural preservation, prosodic patterns, collective intelligence Summary: This research introduces a computational social science approach to safeguarding Telugu Chandassu, a metrical poetry tradition embodying centuries of cultural wisdom. By blending traditional community knowledge with modern computational methods, the study develops a digital framework for analyzing Telugu prosodic patterns. The framework involves collaborative dataset creation, expert-validated linguistic patterns, and culturally-informed algorithmic design. Key components include AksharamTokenizer for prosody-aware tokenization, LaghuvuGuruvu Generator for distinguishing light and heavy syllables, and PadyaBhedam Checker for automated pattern recognition. The algorithm achieves high accuracy on the Chandassu Score, aligned with traditional literary standards. Through this work, computational social science is showcased as a tool to safeguard endangered cultural knowledge systems and cultivate collective intelligence around literary heritage. The methodology also offers valuable insights for community-centered cultural preservation efforts, supporting broader initiatives in digital humanities and socially-aware computing systems.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01233v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: This research presents a computational social science approach to preserving Telugu Chandassu, the metrical poetry tradition representing centuries of collective cultural intelligence. We develop the first comprehensive digital framework for analyzing Telugu prosodic patterns, bridging traditional community knowledge with modern computational methods. Our social computing approach involves collaborative dataset creation of 4,651 annotated padyams, expert-validated linguistic patterns, and culturally-informed algorithmic design. The framework includes AksharamTokenizer for prosody-aware tokenization, LaghuvuGuruvu Generator for classifying light and heavy syllables, and PadyaBhedam Checker for automated pattern recognition. Our algorithm achieves 91.73% accuracy on the proposed Chandassu Score, with evaluation metrics reflecting traditional literary standards. This work demonstrates how computational social science can preserve endangered cultural knowledge systems while enabling new forms of collective intelligence around literary heritage. The methodology offers insights for community-centered approaches to cultural preservation, supporting broader initiatives in digital humanities and socially-aware computing systems.

item.title: LLMRank: Understanding LLM Strengths for Model Routing
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, efficiency, neural ranking model, feature extraction, transparent deployment Summary: The article introduces LLMRank, a framework for selecting the most suitable large language model based on prompts to optimize performance and efficiency. It leverages human-readable features extracted from prompts, task type, reasoning patterns, complexity indicators, syntactic cues, and signals from a lightweight proxy solver. LLMRank utilizes a neural ranking model trained on RouterBench to predict per-model utility, achieving up to 89.2% of oracle utility. The approach provides interpretable feature attributions that explain routing decisions. Extensive studies demonstrate the importance of multifaceted feature extraction and the hybrid ranking objective in efficient and transparent deployment of large language models. Overall, LLMRank showcases the potential of feature-driven routing for optimizing the trade-off between performance and efficiency in deploying large language models.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01234v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: The rapid growth of large language models (LLMs) with diverse capabilities, latency and computational costs presents a critical deployment challenge: selecting the most suitable model for each prompt to optimize the trade-off between performance and efficiency. We introduce LLMRank, a prompt-aware routing framework that leverages rich, human-readable features extracted from prompts, including task type, reasoning patterns, complexity indicators, syntactic cues, and signals from a lightweight proxy solver. Unlike prior one-shot routers that rely solely on latent embeddings, LLMRank predicts per-model utility using a neural ranking model trained on RouterBench, comprising 36,497 prompts spanning 11 benchmarks and 11 state-of-the-art LLMs, from small efficient models to large frontier systems. Our approach achieves up to 89.2% of oracle utility, while providing interpretable feature attributions that explain routing decisions. Extensive studies demonstrate the importance of multifaceted feature extraction and the hybrid ranking objective, highlighting the potential of feature-driven routing for efficient and transparent LLM deployment.

item.title: GRPO++: Enhancing Dermatological Reasoning under Low Resource Settings
item.content:encoded:
GRPO++, DermIQ-VLM, dermatology, structured reasoning, medical image analysis

Summary:
DermIQ-VLM is a new Vision-Language Model (VLM) developed for dermatology using a resource-efficient methodology. The model, trained using a modified version of GRPO called GRPO++, combines reasoning-oriented disease recognition with supervised fine-tuning for conversational ability. To address factual errors, the model is aligned using Direct Preference Optimization (DPO) with a Knowledge Graph-based system. Evaluation on a dermatological dataset shows significant performance gains over standard fine-tuning approaches. This methodology demonstrates the potential of developing specialized, reliable VLMs in resource-constrained environments.
arXiv:2510.01236v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Vision-Language Models (VLMs) show promise in medical image analysis, yet their capacity for structured reasoning in complex domains like dermatology is often limited by data scarcity and the high computational cost of advanced training techniques. To address these challenges, we introduce DermIQ-VLM, a VLM developed through a multi-stage, resource-efficient methodology designed to emulate a dermatologist's diagnostic process. Our primary contribution is a modified version of Grouped Relative Policy Optimization (GRPO), called GRPO++, which stabilizes the powerful but data-intensive GRPO framework. Our proposed training pipeline first employs GRPO++ for reasoning-oriented disease recognition, followed by supervised fine-tuning for conversational ability. To mitigate factual errors introduced during this step, we then align the model using Direct Preference Optimization (DPO), leveraging a Knowledge Graph-based system as a scalable proxy for expert preference. A preliminary evaluation on a curated dermatological dataset demonstrates that our proposed methodology yields notable performance gains over standard fine-tuning approaches. These findings validate the potential of our pipeline as a feasible pathway for developing specialized, reliable VLMs in resource-constrained environments.

item.title: Confidence-Aware Routing for Large Language Model Reliability Enhancement: A Multi-Signal Approach to Pre-Generation Hallucination Mitigation
item.content:encoded:
confidence, routing system, hallucination detection, knowledge-intensive QA, reliability enhancement Summary: This article introduces a confidence-aware routing system for Large Language Models (LLMs) to reduce hallucination in generated content. The system proactively assesses model uncertainty before generation using signals such as semantic alignment, internal convergence analysis, and confidence estimation. Based on the unified confidence score, queries are redirected to different pathways: local generation, retrieval-augmented generation, larger models, or human review. Evaluation on knowledge-intensive QA benchmarks shows improved hallucination detection and reduced computational costs compared to post-hoc methods. The F1 score also increases with low false positive rates, demonstrating the effectiveness of the proactive assessment approach in enhancing LLM reliability. This paradigm shift from reactive correction to proactive assessment offers a computationally efficient way to improve the reliability of LLM-generated content.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01237v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models suffer from hallucination, generating plausible yet factually incorrect content. Current mitigation strategies focus on post-generation correction, which is computationally expensive and fails to prevent unreliable content generation. We propose a confidence-aware routing system that proactively assesses model uncertainty before generation and redirects queries based on estimated reliability. Our approach combines three complementary signals: semantic alignment between internal representations and reference embeddings, internal convergence analysis across model layers, and learned confidence estimation. The unified confidence score determines routing to four pathways: local generation for high confidence, retrieval-augmented generation for medium confidence, larger models for low confidence, and human review for very low confidence. Evaluation on knowledge-intensive QA benchmarks demonstrates significant improvements in hallucination detection (0.74 vs. 0.42 baseline) while reducing computational costs by 40% compared to post-hoc methods. The F1 score improves from 0.61 to 0.82 with low false positive rates (0.09). This paradigm shift from reactive correction to proactive assessment offers a computationally efficient approach to LLM reliability enhancement.

item.title: Silent Tokens, Loud Effects: Padding in LLMs
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: padding tokens, language models, batched inference, hidden representations, robustness risk
Summary:
The study investigates the impact of padding tokens on large language models (LLMs). It explores how even small amounts of padding can affect hidden representations, degrade generation quality in smaller models, and unpredictably alter bias. The research also found that padding weakens safety guardrails in LLMs. The study conducted assessments across three open-source model families - Llama, Gemma, and Qwen - and evaluated outcomes on activations, generation quality, bias, and safety. The results show that the influence of padding tokens is not well understood and can pose robustness risks in LLM deployment. Hence, it is crucial to handle padding carefully to mitigate these risks.
arXiv:2510.01238v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Padding tokens are widely used in large language models (LLMs) to equalize sequence lengths during batched inference. While they should be fully masked, implementation errors can cause them to influence computation, and the extent of this influence is not well understood. We systematically study this effect across three open-source model families (Llama, Gemma, Qwen), inserting controlled amounts of padding and evaluating outcomes along four axes: activations, generation quality, bias, and safety. Even small amounts of padding shift hidden representations, degrade quality in smaller models, alter bias in unpredictable ways, and weaken safety guardrails. These findings demonstrate that padding is not a harmless detail but a robustness risk that must be carefully handled in deployment.

item.title: CIFLEX: Contextual Instruction Flow for Sub-task Execution in Multi-Turn Interactions with a Single On-Device LLM
item.content:encoded:
<div> cache, sub-task handling, large language model, on-device, multi-turn interactions
Summary: CIFLEX introduces an execution system for efficient sub-task handling in multi-turn interactions using a single on-device large language model (LLM). Traditional approaches incur high computational overhead by reprocessing the entire conversation context when switching between main and sub-tasks. CIFLEX addresses this issue by reusing the main task's key-value cache and injecting task-specific instructions into isolated side paths for sub-task execution. The model seamlessly transitions back to the main path using cached context, eliminating redundant computation. Additionally, a hierarchical classification strategy is developed for sub-task selection, simplifying decision-making for smaller models. Experiments demonstrate that CIFLEX significantly reduces computational costs while maintaining task performance, enabling scalable and efficient multi-task dialogues on-device. <div> arXiv:2510.01239v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: We present CIFLEX (Contextual Instruction Flow for Sub-task Execution), which is a novel execution system for efficient sub-task handling in multi-turn interactions with a single on-device large language model (LLM). As LLMs become increasingly capable, a single model is expected to handle diverse sub-tasks that more effectively and comprehensively support answering user requests. Naive approach reprocesses the entire conversation context when switching between main and sub-tasks (e.g., query rewriting, summarization), incurring significant computational overhead. CIFLEX mitigates this overhead by reusing the key-value (KV) cache from the main task and injecting only task-specific instructions into isolated side paths. After sub-task execution, the model rolls back to the main path via cached context, thereby avoiding redundant prefill computation. To support sub-task selection, we also develop a hierarchical classification strategy tailored for small-scale models, decomposing multi-choice decisions into binary ones. Experiments show that CIFLEX significantly reduces computational costs without degrading task performance, enabling scalable and efficient multi-task dialogue on-device.

item.title: SKYLENAGE Technical Report: Mathematical Reasoning and Contest-Innovation Benchmarks for Multi-Level Math Evaluation
item.content:encoded:
Large language models, LLM, mathematics, SKYLENAGE-ReasoningMATH, SKYLENAGE-MATH Summary: SKYLENAGE introduces two benchmarks for evaluating large language models in mathematics: SKYLENAGE-ReasoningMATH, a diagnostic set with metadata on complexity; and SKYLENAGE-MATH, a contest-style suite spanning different education stages. Fifteen LLM variants were tested, with the best model achieving 44% accuracy on the contest suite and 81% on the reasoning set. Results showed a decline in accuracy from high school to doctoral level, with top systems retaining 79% proficiency. The benchmarks provide a challenging evaluation of mathematical reasoning skills, highlighting robustness gaps between top-performing models and mid-tier systems. SKYLENAGE offers a comprehensive and structured math benchmark, serving as a valuable resource for future assessments of LLMs in mathematical reasoning.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01241v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models (LLMs) now perform strongly on many public math suites, yet frontier separation within mathematics increasingly suffers from ceiling effects. We present two complementary benchmarks: SKYLENAGE-ReasoningMATH, a 100-item, structure-aware diagnostic set with per-item metadata on length, numeric density, and symbolic complexity; and SKYLENAGE-MATH, a 150-item contest-style suite spanning four stages from high school to doctoral under a seven-subject taxonomy. We evaluate fifteen contemporary LLM variants under a single setup and analyze subject x model and grade x model performance. On the contest suite, the strongest model reaches 44% while the runner-up reaches 37%; accuracy declines from high school to doctoral, and top systems exhibit a doctoral-to-high-school retention near 79%. On the reasoning set, the best model attains 81% overall, and hardest-slice results reveal clear robustness gaps between leaders and the mid-tier. In summary, we release SKYLENAGE-ReasoningMATH and report aggregate results for SKYLENAGE-MATH; together, SKYLENAGE provides a hard, reasoning-centered and broadly covering math benchmark with calibrated difficulty and rich metadata, serving as a reference benchmark for future evaluations of mathematical reasoning.

item.title: Redundancy-as-Masking: Formalizing the Artificial Age Score (AAS) to Model Memory Aging in Generative AI
item.content:encoded:
age, artificial intelligence, memory performance, episodic details, semantic cues Summary:
- Artificial intelligence ages not through chronological time but through structural asymmetries in memory performance. - The Artificial Age Score (AAS) is introduced as a metric of memory aging derived from observable recall behavior. - AAS is well-defined, bounded, and monotonic, applicable across various tasks and domains. - Redundancy-as-Masking formulation interprets redundancy as overlapping information reducing penalized mass. - The AAS framework was tested in a bilingual study with ChatGPT-5, showing structural memory aging when episodic continuity was not maintained. These findings support AAS as a diagnostic tool for evaluating memory degradation in artificial systems. The study integrates concepts from von Neumann, Shannon, and Turing. Summary:
arXiv:2510.01242v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Artificial intelligence is observed to age not through chronological time but through structural asymmetries in memory performance. In large language models, semantic cues such as the name of the day often remain stable across sessions, while episodic details like the sequential progression of experiment numbers tend to collapse when conversational context is reset. To capture this phenomenon, the Artificial Age Score (AAS) is introduced as a log-scaled, entropy-informed metric of memory aging derived from observable recall behavior. The score is formally proven to be well-defined, bounded, and monotonic under mild and model-agnostic assumptions, making it applicable across various tasks and domains. In its Redundancy-as-Masking formulation, the score interprets redundancy as overlapping information that reduces the penalized mass. However, in the present study, redundancy is not explicitly estimated; all reported values assume a redundancy-neutral setting (R = 0), yielding conservative upper bounds. The AAS framework was tested over a 25-day bilingual study involving ChatGPT-5, structured into stateless and persistent interaction phases. During persistent sessions, the model consistently recalled both semantic and episodic details, driving the AAS toward its theoretical minimum, indicative of structural youth. In contrast, when sessions were reset, the model preserved semantic consistency but failed to maintain episodic continuity, causing a sharp increase in the AAS and signaling structural memory aging. These findings support the utility of AAS as a theoretically grounded, task-independent diagnostic tool for evaluating memory degradation in artificial systems. The study builds on foundational concepts from von Neumann's work on automata, Shannon's theories of information and redundancy, and Turing's behavioral approach to intelligence.

item.title: Detoxifying Large Language Models via Autoregressive Reward Guided Representation Editing
item.content:encoded:
<div> detoxification, large language models, toxic content, reward-guided editing, test-time methods
Summary: Autoregressive Reward Guided Representation Editing (ARGRE) is a novel test-time detoxification framework designed to address the challenge of imprecise interventions in Large Language Models (LLMs) that generate toxic content. ARGRE models toxicity transitions within the latent representation space to provide stable and precise editing guidance. By identifying non-toxic semantic directions and interpolating between toxic and non-toxic representations, ARGRE transforms sparse toxicity annotations into dense training signals. At inference, ARGRE utilizes an autoregressive reward model to guide a two-step editing process that effectively detoxifies LLM representations. Extensive experiments across 8 LLMs demonstrate that ARGRE outperforms leading baselines in both effectiveness and efficiency, reducing toxicity by 62.21% and inference time by 47.58%. This framework allows for safe and responsible deployment of LLMs while maintaining their core capabilities with minimal degradation. <div> arXiv:2510.01243v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large Language Models (LLMs) have demonstrated impressive performance across various tasks, yet they remain vulnerable to generating toxic content, necessitating detoxification strategies to ensure safe and responsible deployment. Test-time detoxification methods, which typically introduce static or dynamic interventions into LLM representations, offer a promising solution due to their flexibility and minimal invasiveness. However, current approaches often suffer from imprecise interventions, primarily due to their insufficient exploration of the transition space between toxic and non-toxic outputs. To address this challenge, we propose \textsc{A}utoregressive \textsc{R}eward \textsc{G}uided \textsc{R}epresentation \textsc{E}diting (ARGRE), a novel test-time detoxification framework that explicitly models toxicity transitions within the latent representation space, enabling stable and precise reward-guided editing. ARGRE identifies non-toxic semantic directions and interpolates between toxic and non-toxic representations to reveal fine-grained transition trajectories. These trajectories transform sparse toxicity annotations into dense training signals, enabling the construction of an autoregressive reward model that delivers stable and precise editing guidance. At inference, the reward model guides an adaptive two-step editing process to obtain detoxified representations: it first performs directional steering based on expected reward gaps to shift representations toward non-toxic regions, followed by lightweight gradient-based refinements. Extensive experiments across 8 widely used LLMs show that ARGRE significantly outperforms leading baselines in effectiveness (-62.21% toxicity) and efficiency (-47.58% inference time), while preserving the core capabilities of the original model with minimal degradation. Our code is available at the website.

item.title: Feasibility of Structuring Stress Documentation Using an Ontology-Guided Large Language Model
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Stress, Ontology, Large Language Model, Narrative Text, Ambient AI
Summary: The study focused on developing an ontology for mental stress, integrating theoretical models with concepts from stress assessment tools. MeSO identified six categories of stress-related information and refined its structure with expert validation. Using MeSO, stress-related information was extracted from Reddit posts using a Large Language Model (LLM). The final ontology included 181 concepts across eight top-level classes. The LLM correctly identified 78.2% of extractable stress-related items, with some misclassifications and missed items. The study demonstrates the feasibility of using an ontology-guided LLM for structured extraction of stress-related information, potentially enhancing stress documentation in ambient AI systems. Future work should involve clinical dialogue data and comparison across LLMs.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01244v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Stress, arising from the dynamic interaction between external stressors, individual appraisals, and physiological or psychological responses, significantly impacts health yet is often underreported and inconsistently documented, typically captured as unstructured free-text in electronic health records. Ambient AI technologies offer promise in reducing documentation burden, but predominantly generate unstructured narratives, limiting downstream clinical utility. This study aimed to develop an ontology for mental stress and evaluate the feasibility of using a Large Language Model (LLM) to extract ontology-guided stress-related information from narrative text. The Mental Stress Ontology (MeSO) was developed by integrating theoretical models like the Transactional Model of Stress with concepts from 11 validated stress assessment tools. MeSO's structure and content were refined using Ontology Pitfall Scanner! and expert validation. Using MeSO, six categories of stress-related information--stressor, stress response, coping strategy, duration, onset, and temporal profile--were extracted from 35 Reddit posts using Claude Sonnet 4. Human reviewers evaluated accuracy and ontology coverage. The final ontology included 181 concepts across eight top-level classes. Of 220 extractable stress-related items, the LLM correctly identified 172 (78.2%), misclassified 27 (12.3%), and missed 21 (9.5%). All correctly extracted items were accurately mapped to MeSO, although 24 relevant concepts were not yet represented in the ontology. This study demonstrates the feasibility of using an ontology-guided LLM for structured extraction of stress-related information, offering potential to enhance the consistency and utility of stress documentation in ambient AI systems. Future work should involve clinical dialogue data and comparison across LLMs.

item.title: SeMob: Semantic Synthesis for Dynamic Urban Mobility Prediction
item.content:encoded:
semantic synthesis pipeline, dynamic mobility prediction, multi-agent framework, LLM-based agents, progressive fusion architecture Summary: SeMob is a novel framework for dynamic mobility prediction that integrates textual descriptions of external events into spatiotemporal models. The system utilizes LLM-powered agents to extract and reason about relevant text data, which is then fused with spatiotemporal information using a progressive fusion architecture. By incorporating rich event priors, SeMob outperforms traditional spatiotemporal models, achieving significant reductions in Mean Absolute Error (MAE) and Root Mean Square Error (RMSE). The framework demonstrates particular strength in predicting mobility patterns near event locations and times, highlighting its effectiveness in accounting for abrupt changes in human mobility. SeMob represents a promising approach to enhancing urban services by improving the accuracy of mobility forecasting models.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01245v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Human mobility prediction is vital for urban services, but often fails to account for abrupt changes from external events. Existing spatiotemporal models struggle to leverage textual descriptions detailing these events. We propose SeMob, an LLM-powered semantic synthesis pipeline for dynamic mobility prediction. Specifically, SeMob employs a multi-agent framework where LLM-based agents automatically extract and reason about spatiotemporally related text from complex online texts. Fine-grained relevant contexts are then incorporated with spatiotemporal data through our proposed innovative progressive fusion architecture. The rich pre-trained event prior contributes enriched insights about event-driven prediction, and hence results in a more aligned forecasting model. Evaluated on a dataset constructed through our pipeline, SeMob achieves maximal reductions of 13.92% in MAE and 11.12% in RMSE compared to the spatiotemporal model. Notably, the framework exhibits pronounced superiority especially within spatiotemporal regions close to an event's location and time of occurrence.

item.title: A Comparative Analysis of Sparse Autoencoder and Activation Difference in Language Model Steering
item.content:encoded:
autoencoders, language model, steering, sparse, mathematical reasoning Summary: Sparse autoencoders (SAEs) have proven to be effective in steering language models, but previous approaches focusing on top-k latents sometimes capture non-semantic features. This study suggests focusing on the most relevant SAE latent (top-1) to eliminate redundant features and enhance semantic attributes. The constant SAE steering method often leads to repetitive single words, so a token-wise decaying steering strategy is introduced to address this issue. By steering an SAE latent associated with reasoning, the model can effectively elicit step-by-step mathematical reasoning and improve inference quality, mimicking the effect of appending a guiding token. Empirical results show that SAEs outperform mean activation difference methods on mathematical reasoning benchmarks and achieve similar performance on IF-Eval. Overall, the proposed approach improves the quality of inference and reasoning in language models using sparse autoencoders.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01246v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Sparse autoencoders (SAEs) have recently emerged as a powerful tool for language model steering. Prior work has explored top-k SAE latents for steering, but we observe that many dimensions among the top-k latents capture non-semantic features such as punctuation rather than semantic attributes like instructions. To address this, we propose focusing on a single, most relevant SAE latent (top-1), eliminating redundant features. We further identify a limitation in constant SAE steering, which often produces degenerate outputs such as repetitive single words. To mitigate this, we introduce a token-wise decaying steering strategy, enabling more faithful comparisons with mean activation difference baselines. Empirically, we show that steering an SAE latent associated with reasoning reliably elicits step-by-step mathematical reasoning and enhances inference quality, functionally resembling the effect of appending a guiding token. Our results demonstrate that SAEs outperform mean activation difference methods on mathematical reasoning benchmarks and match their performance on IF-Eval.

item.title: Let's Play Across Cultures: A Large Multilingual, Multicultural Benchmark for Assessing Language Models' Understanding of Sports
item.content:encoded:
sports, Language Models, CultSportQA, traditional, benchmark Summary: CultSportQA introduces a benchmark to evaluate Language Models' understanding of traditional sports globally, covering 60 countries and 6 continents and encompassing four cultural categories. The dataset includes 33,000 multiple-choice questions categorized into history-based, rule-based, and scenario-based types. Various model performance evaluation techniques such as zero-shot, few-shot, and chain-of-thought prompting are utilized with different types of language models. The benchmark aims to assess AI's ability to comprehend and reason about traditional sports across linguistic and cultural diversity, setting a new standard in this field.

arXiv:2510.01247v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Language Models (LMs) are primarily evaluated on globally popular sports, often overlooking regional and indigenous sporting traditions. To address this gap, we introduce \textbf{\textit{CultSportQA}}, a benchmark designed to assess LMs' understanding of traditional sports across 60 countries and 6 continents, encompassing four distinct cultural categories. The dataset features 33,000 multiple-choice questions (MCQs) across text and image modalities, each of which is categorized into three key types: history-based, rule-based, and scenario-based. To evaluate model performance, we employ zero-shot, few-shot, and chain-of-thought (CoT) prompting across a diverse set of Large Language Models (LLMs), Small Language Models (SLMs), and Multimodal Large Language Models (MLMs). By providing a comprehensive multilingual and multicultural sports benchmark, \textbf{\textit{CultSportQA}} establishes a new standard for assessing AI's ability to understand and reason about traditional sports.

item.title: SSTAG: Structure-Aware Self-Supervised Learning Method for Text-Attributed Graphs
item.content:encoded:
self supervised learning, text attributed graphs, large language models, graph neural networks, knowledge distillation Summary: The paper introduces a novel structure aware self supervised learning method, SSTAG, designed for Text Attributed Graphs (TAGs). This method aims to bridge the semantic reasoning of Large Language Models (LLMs) with the structural modeling capabilities of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs) to enhance the scalability of large-scale TAGs. SSTAG utilizes a dual knowledge distillation framework to co-distill LLMs and GNNs into structure-aware multilayer perceptrons (MLPs). Additionally, an in-memory mechanism is introduced to store typical graph representations and align them with memory anchors in an in-memory repository to integrate invariant knowledge, thereby improving generalization ability. Extensive experiments show that SSTAG surpasses existing models in cross-domain transfer learning tasks, offers exceptional scalability, and reduces inference costs while maintaining competitive performance.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01248v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large scale pretrained models have revolutionized Natural Language Processing (NLP) and Computer Vision (CV), showcasing remarkable cross domain generalization abilities. However, in graph learning, models are typically trained on individual graph datasets, limiting their capacity to transfer knowledge across different graphs and tasks. This approach also heavily relies on large volumes of annotated data, which presents a significant challenge in resource-constrained settings. Unlike NLP and CV, graph structured data presents unique challenges due to its inherent heterogeneity, including domain specific feature spaces and structural diversity across various applications. To address these challenges, we propose a novel structure aware self supervised learning method for Text Attributed Graphs (SSTAG). By leveraging text as a unified representation medium for graph learning, SSTAG bridges the gap between the semantic reasoning of Large Language Models (LLMs) and the structural modeling capabilities of Graph Neural Networks (GNNs). Our approach introduces a dual knowledge distillation framework that co-distills both LLMs and GNNs into structure-aware multilayer perceptrons (MLPs), enhancing the scalability of large-scale TAGs. Additionally, we introduce an in-memory mechanism that stores typical graph representations, aligning them with memory anchors in an in-memory repository to integrate invariant knowledge, thereby improving the model's generalization ability. Extensive experiments demonstrate that SSTAG outperforms state-of-the-art models on cross-domain transfer learning tasks, achieves exceptional scalability, and reduces inference costs while maintaining competitive performance.

item.title: LOCA: Logical Chain Augmentation for Scientific Corpus Cleaning
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large Language Models, scientific question-answering, LOCA, logical chain augmentation, high-quality scientific corpora Summary: LOCA (Logical Chain Augmentation) is a framework designed to improve the reliability of scientific question-answering datasets used by Large Language Models (LLMs). Existing datasets often suffer from high error rates due to logical leaps and implicit reasoning in the answers. LOCA addresses this issue by enhancing raw answers, completing missing logical steps, and separating scientific principles from their derivations. By applying LOCA, noisy datasets can be filtered, reducing error rates from 20% to below 2%. This framework provides a scalable and effective method for creating high-quality scientific corpora, enabling more reliable training and evaluation of scientific AI.

Summary: LOCA, a framework for enhancing scientific question-answering datasets, addresses high error rates by completing missing logical steps and improving the quality of scientific corpora used by Large Language Models.
arXiv:2510.01249v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: While Large Language Models (LLMs) excel in general domains, their reliability often falls short in scientific problem-solving. The advancement of scientific AI depends on large-scale, high-quality corpora. However, existing scientific question-answering (QA) datasets suffer from high error rates, frequently resulting from logical leaps and implicit reasoning within the answers. To address this issue, we introduce LOCA (Logical Chain Augmentation), a novel framework for automatically cleaning scientific corpora, implemented through an augment-and-review loop. At its core, LOCA enhances raw answers by completing missing logical steps and explicitly separating the underlying scientific principle from its subsequent derivation. By applying LOCA to challenging scientific corpora, we demonstrate that it can automatically filter noisy datasets, typically reducing the error rate from as high as 20\% to below 2\%. LOCA provides a scalable and effective methodology for creating high-quality scientific corpora, paving the way for more reliable training and evaluation of scientific AI.

item.title: GemDetox at TextDetox CLEF 2025: Enhancing a Massively Multilingual Model for Text Detoxification on Low-resource Languages
item.content:encoded:
transformer; detoxification challenge; paraphrase; multilingual; social media
Summary: Our submission to the PAN 2025 Multilingual Text Detoxification Challenge focuses on rewriting toxic single-sentence inputs into neutral paraphrases across 15 languages. We utilize a 12B-parameter Gemma-3 multilingual transformer and apply parameter-efficient LoRA SFT fine-tuning and prompting techniques like few-shot and Chain-of-Thought. Our training corpus includes human-authored parallel pairs, machine-translated synthetic pairs, and model-generated pairs. During inference, inputs are enriched with LaBSE-retrieved neighbors and toxic-span annotations. Our system ranks first in both high-resource and low-resource languages based on Style Transfer Accuracy, semantic preservation, and fluency evaluations. Ablation studies reveal performance improvements from few-shot examples and CoT prompting. ANOVA analysis highlights language resource status as a significant performance predictor.

Summary: Our submission to the PAN 2025 Multilingual Text Detoxification Challenge leverages a Gemma-3 multilingual transformer to rewrite toxic inputs into neutral paraphrases across diverse languages. By incorporating various training data sources and advanced techniques like LoRA SFT fine-tuning and prompting, we achieve top rankings in both high-resource and low-resource languages. Ablation studies and ANOVA analysis further demonstrate the effectiveness of our approach.
arXiv:2510.01250v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As social-media platforms emerge and evolve faster than the regulations meant to oversee them, automated detoxification might serve as a timely tool for moderators to enforce safe discourse at scale. We here describe our submission to the PAN 2025 Multilingual Text Detoxification Challenge, which rewrites toxic single-sentence inputs into neutral paraphrases across 15 typologically diverse languages. Building on a 12B-parameter Gemma-3 multilingual transformer, we apply parameter-efficient LoRA SFT fine-tuning and prompting techniques like few-shot and Chain-of-Thought. Our multilingual training corpus combines 3,600 human-authored parallel pairs, 21,600 machine-translated synthetic pairs, and model-generated pairs filtered by Jaccard thresholds. At inference, inputs are enriched with three LaBSE-retrieved neighbors and explicit toxic-span annotations. Evaluated via Style Transfer Accuracy, LaBSE-based semantic preservation, and xCOMET fluency, our system ranks first on high-resource and low-resource languages. Ablations show +0.081 joint score increase from few-shot examples and +0.088 from basic CoT prompting. ANOVA analysis identifies language resource status as the strongest predictor of performance ($\eta^2$ = 0.667, p < 0.01).

item.title: Efficient Uncertainty Estimation for LLM-based Entity Linking in Tabular Data
item.content:encoded:
Entity Linking, Tabular Data, Large Language Models, Uncertainty Estimation, Self-Supervised Approach

Summary:
The article discusses the challenge of linking textual values in tabular data to entities in a Knowledge Base using Large Language Models (LLMs). While LLMs excel at Entity Linking (EL), their practical deployment requires accurate predictions and reliable uncertainty estimates. The study explores a self-supervised approach to estimate uncertainty from single-shot LLM outputs using token-level features, reducing the need for resource-intensive multi-shot inference. Evaluation on an EL task reveals that the method effectively identifies low-accuracy outputs at a lower computational cost, making it a cost-effective solution for integrating uncertainty measures into LLM-based EL workflows. By providing a practical way to incorporate uncertainty estimation into EL workflows with minimal computational overhead, the approach enhances the usability and efficiency of LLMs in real-world applications.
arXiv:2510.01251v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Linking textual values in tabular data to their corresponding entities in a Knowledge Base is a core task across a variety of data integration and enrichment applications. Although Large Language Models (LLMs) have shown State-of-The-Art performance in Entity Linking (EL) tasks, their deployment in real-world scenarios requires not only accurate predictions but also reliable uncertainty estimates, which require resource-demanding multi-shot inference, posing serious limits to their actual applicability. As a more efficient alternative, we investigate a self-supervised approach for estimating uncertainty from single-shot LLM outputs using token-level features, reducing the need for multiple generations. Evaluation is performed on an EL task on tabular data across multiple LLMs, showing that the resulting uncertainty estimates are highly effective in detecting low-accuracy outputs. This is achieved at a fraction of the computational cost, ultimately supporting a cost-effective integration of uncertainty measures into LLM-based EL workflows. The method offers a practical way to incorporate uncertainty estimation into EL workflows with limited computational overhead.

item.title: GPT and Prejudice: A Sparse Approach to Understanding Learned Representations in Large Language Models
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: large language models, sparse autoencoders, model interpretations, societal constructs, bias discovery

Summary: Large language models (LLMs) are being trained on vast, unfiltered datasets, posing challenges in understanding their representations and the underlying data. By coupling LLMs with sparse autoencoders (SAEs), this study explores the interpretability of not only model behavior but also the inherent structures, themes, and biases within the training data. Using a GPT-style transformer model trained exclusively on Jane Austen's novels, known for rich social constructs and narrative patterns, SAEs are applied to hidden states across different layers. This approach reveals sparse, interpretable features reflecting key narratives and concepts such as gender, class, and societal duty present in the corpus. The combination of LLMs and SAEs serves as scalable tools for delving into complex datasets, facilitating corpus exploration, bias identification, and model interpretability on a larger scale.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01252v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: As large language models (LLMs) are increasingly trained on massive, uncurated corpora, understanding both model representations and the data they internalize has become a major challenge. In this work, we show that pairing LLMs with sparse autoencoders (SAEs) enables interpretation not only of model behavior but also of the deeper structures, themes, and biases embedded in the training data. We train a GPT-style transformer model exclusively on the novels of Jane Austen, a corpus rich in social constructs and narrative patterns. We then apply SAEs to hidden states across multiple layers, uncovering sparse, interpretable features that reflect the key narratives and concepts present in the corpus, including gender, class, and societal duty. Our findings demonstrate that LLMs combined with SAEs can act as scalable probes into complex datasets, offering a new path for corpus exploration, bias discovery, and model interpretability at scale.

item.title: Do Bias Benchmarks Generalise? Evidence from Voice-based Evaluation of Gender Bias in SpeechLLMs
item.content:encoded:
benchmarking bias fairness speech large language models, multiple-choice question answering, MCQA behaviours, long-form creative generation tasks, evaluation suite
Summary:
Recent work in benchmarking bias and fairness in SpeechLLMs focused on MCQA formats, assuming model performance consistency across tasks. However, fine-tuning models to prefer stereotypical, anti-stereotypical, or neutral/uncertain answers showed inconsistent generalization to other MCQA benchmarks and long-form tasks. Performance on MCQA bias benchmarks did not reliably predict across tasks, highlighting limited cross-task generalization in the speech domain. An evaluation suite is proposed for measuring behavior transferability in future models and benchmarks.
arXiv:2510.01254v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Recent work in benchmarking bias and fairness in speech large language models (SpeechLLMs) has relied heavily on multiple-choice question answering (MCQA) formats. The model is tasked to choose between stereotypical, anti-stereotypical, or neutral/irrelevant answers given an input speech prompt and an optional text prompt. Such MCQA benchmarks implicitly assume that model performance is consistent across other MCQA tasks, voices, and other task formats such as more realistic, long-form evaluations. In this paper, we probe that assumption. We fine-tune three SpeechLLMs using LoRA adapters to induce specific MCQA behaviours: preference for stereotypical, anti-stereotypical, or neutral/uncertain answers. We then evaluate whether these behaviours generalise to another, distinct MCQA benchmark, and more critically to long-form, creative generation tasks. Our results show that performance on MCQA bias benchmarks fails to reliably predict performances across other MCQA benchmarks, and more importantly across long-form tasks. We conclude that current MCQA bias benchmarks show limited evidence of cross-task generalisation in the speech domain, and also propose an evaluation suite for measuring behaviour transferability in future models and benchmarks.

item.title: Longitudinal Monitoring of LLM Content Moderation of Social Issues
item.content:encoded:
Keywords: Large language models, content moderation, AI Watchman, transparency, longitudinal auditing Summary: The study focuses on the impact of opaque content moderation practices on the outputs of large language models (LLMs). The researchers introduce AI Watchman, a system designed to track and measure LLM refusals over time to provide transparency into this aspect of LLM behavior. By auditing Open AI's models, GPT-4.1, GPT-5, and DeepSeek in both English and Chinese, the study reveals that changes in company policies can be detected through AI Watchman, highlighting differences in content moderation practices between models. The research also categorizes different forms of refusal by LLMs. This work underscores the importance of longitudinal auditing in understanding and addressing the impact of company policies on LLM outputs, providing valuable insights for ensuring transparency and accountability in the use of these models.

Summary:
arXiv:2510.01255v1 Announce Type: new Abstract: Large language models' (LLMs') outputs are shaped by opaque and frequently-changing company content moderation policies and practices. LLM moderation often takes the form of refusal; models' refusal to produce text about certain topics both reflects company policy and subtly shapes public discourse. We introduce AI Watchman, a longitudinal auditing system to publicly measure and track LLM refusals over time, to provide transparency into an important and black-box aspect of LLMs. Using a dataset of over 400 social issues, we audit Open AI's moderation endpoint, GPT-4.1, and GPT-5, and DeepSeek (both in English and Chinese). We find evidence that changes in company policies, even those not publicly announced, can be detected by AI Watchman, and identify company- and model-specific differences in content moderation. We also qualitatively analyze and categorize different forms of refusal. This work contributes evidence for the value of longitudinal auditing of LLMs, and AI Watchman, one system for doing so.

item.title: RJE: A Retrieval-Judgment-Exploration Framework for Efficient Knowledge Graph Question Answering with LLMs
item.content:encoded:
<div> Knowledge graph question answering, KGQA, large language models, LLMs, Retrieval-Judgment-Exploration, RJE.
Summary: Retrieval-Judgment-Exploration (RJE) is a framework designed to improve knowledge graph question answering (KGQA) by refining reasoning paths, evaluating sufficiency, and exploring additional evidence. RJE enhances the performance of small-sized LLMs, such as GPT-4o-mini, by introducing specialized auxiliary modules like Reasoning Path Ranking, Question Decomposition, and Retriever-assisted Exploration. This approach outperforms existing baselines and allows small open-source LLMs with 3B and 8B parameters to achieve competitive results without fine-tuning.
